comments.content: -=®=- I’m hoping someone today could give me an opinion. sorry to seem pushy, but enquiring minds want to know... If you were in receipt of a scientific report on legibility and the only typographic reference cited was _The Thames Hudson Manual of Typography_, would that tell you anything? I am not familiar with the book.

_...would that tell you anything?_

Perhaps, but what of the typography of the report itself?

-=®=-  
fugedaboudit. it sucks.

(editing out now unintelligible remark based on April 1 Typophile strangeness.)

-=®=-

the thing about such reports is that the people who they are written for won’t know good typography or why it matters if it hits them on the head.

... Not their fault. They may know things I don’t, which could even be why they make more money than me. :-)

-=®=-

Russell, I purchased this book back in the mid-90s, for my first book design project, and it was very helpful. Even though some of the information in the book might be considered outdated nowadays, the chapters on book design, the parts of a book, paper, lettering, calligraphy, and printing are all useful. And I, for one, think that even the “outdated” parts are still useful, the same way that I find it useful to know where terms like [leading](http://web.archive.org/web/20081208191505/http:/typophile.com/wiki/leading) come from.

[EDIT] P.S.: Bear in mind that the book’s author, Ruari McLean, was British, so you’ll encounter terms like “jobbing” throughout the text.

Thanks

-=®=-
One of the best books on typography around, despite its being now extremely dated. The fundamentals don’t change, and Ruari McLean did a very good job of outlining the essentials of the profession.

I have the book, and I loved it. A good read for those interested in how they did things the good, old-fashioned way.

And I second the comment about designing for books.
Hey Ricardo, “jobbing” may be outdated, but it’s not a Britishism. It was used quite frequently on this side of the pond also.

Thanks, Kent — good to know.

(I won’t edit my comment to avoid changing the order of the thread.)

Jobbing is more a term from an older era so you can say old farts like me are more likely to know it than GenX no-matter which side of the pond they plunked their froggy :-)

ChrisL
This only goes to prove that, unlike froggies, “old farts” should never, ever croak. :-)

Unless Ricardo makes us die laughing :-)

ChrisL

_plunked their froggy_ is this an oblique reference to ’Andy’s Gang’? As in, “Froggy, pluck your magic twanger.”

RE: the book. Good clean result of a long train of traditional practice. However, it does strike me that the observations about style of letter express the insular point of view of typographic tradition developed by the English after World War II. Valid opinions but not exclusively correct.

”...is this an oblique reference to ’Andy’s Gang’? As in, “Froggy, pluck your magic twanger.””

Yes! It certainly is! Charles, you have given away your age! :-)

You must be a bit younger than me or you would have called it “Smillin” Ed’s Gang” instead of Andy but you are not a young dude by any means :-)

ChrisL

and it is actually “plunk” instead of “Pluck”.

ChrisL
